qas.question: Who was similar recommended intake volumes as adults?
Other then breastfeeding women, who what other category of woman should have increased water intake?
How much more water should pregnant women consumed compared to an average non - pregnant woman?
Why should lactating women increase their water consumption?

answers.text: To compensate for additional fluid output

qas.question: How much more water do lactating women need to consume in relation to the average woman?

context: The EFSA panel also determined intakes for different populations. Recommended intake volumes in <a0_0>the elderly<a0_0/> are the same as for adults as despite lower energy consumption, the water requirement of this group is increased due to a reduction in renal concentrating capacity. <a1_0>Pregnant<a1_0/> and breastfeeding women require additional fluids to stay hydrated. The EFSA panel proposes that pregnant women should consume the same volume of water as non-pregnant women, plus an increase in proportion to the higher energy requirement, equal to <a2_0>300 mL/day<a2_0/>. <a3_0>To compensate for additional fluid output<a3_0/>, breastfeeding women require an additional <a4_0>700 mL/day<a4_0/> above the recommended intake values for non-lactating women.
